name: Relative Wealth Model for Philippines
description: This is an sklearn Random Forest (RF) regressor model for predicting relative wealth for the Philippines. Through a post-training binning process, the model also predicts a quintile-grouped relative wealth category ('A' to 'E')  It is a single-country model trained on open datasets from Earth Observation Group (EOG) nightlights data, Open Streetmap (OSM) Points of Interest (POI) data, Ookla internet speed data as well as Domestic and Health Survey (DHS) data from USAID.  It was built as part of the UNICEF AI4D Relative Wealth Project which aims to develop open datasets and machine learning (ML) models for relative wealth estimation across nine countries  in Southeast Asia (SEA).

links.description: Philippines Relative Wealth Model Weights (.pkl). See related notebook links for usage

links.name: 2023-02-21-ph-rollout-output.csv
links.description: Country wide rollout (inference) of the Relative Wealth Model on Philippines using 2.4km grids (bingtile quadkey level 14)
Training dataset for Relative Wealth Model on Philippines
links.name: 2023-02-21-ph-dhs-cluster-features-all

links.description: Philippines Model Rollout Part 1 (Train Model)
Philippines Model Rollout Part 2 (Generate Grids)
Philippines Model Rollout Part 3 (Rollout Model)
UNICEF AI4D Relative Wealth Project Github Repository
You can setup a local development environment to view and run the jupyter notebooks used to develop the  model and roll it out country-wide.

You can run an interactive dialog that will rollout the relative wealth model for different time periods using this model by  running it via docker. Follow the instructions on the item for "Country-wide rollout".

name: Air Quality Model for Thailand
description: This project explored PM2.5 estimation using Machine Learning models in Thailand. Air pollution is a pressing health concern worldwide, and thus, its monitoring is important for epidemological studies and informing public policy. However, ground sensors (whether reference grade or low-cost) are sparse. For example, in Mueang Chiang Mai, there are only a few air quality sensors based on OpenAQ data. Using Machine Learning models to predict PM2.5 levels based on area predictors is a potential way to augment these ground stations, and allows us to monitor air quality even in areas without them.

link.description: Manuscript - see Section 3.3 Evaluation and Metrics

links.name: predictions_chiangmai_2021.csv
links.description: air quality predictions for chiangmai for the year 2021

links.name: 2022-05-18-base-table-openaq-filt.csv
links.description: Table generated from OpenAQ PM2.5 values.This file also contains the same columns as the air4thai one, but with the additional sensor_type column. This indicated which type of sensor was used to measure PM2.5 value in each station per day. This is the latest, best dataset we have for ML modelling. The other datasets were preserved for replicating the experiments.

links.name: 2022-05-31--base-table-openaq-refgrade.csv
links.description: Derivation of 2022-05-18-base-table-openaq-filt, filtering observations to sensor_type == "reference grade"

links.name: 2022-05-31-base-table-openaq-lowcost.csv
links.description: Derivation of 2022-05-18-base-table-openaq-filt, filtering observations to sensor_type == "low cost"

links.name: 2022-05-31-patched-openaq.csv
links.description: Table patched from the sub-regression model experiment. Missing MAIAC AOD values were predicted using a model trained using CAM AOD data.  These predictions were appended to the existing AOD data used for training the AOD model.  This patched table was then used to predict PM 2.5 values
UNICEF AI4D Air Quality Github Repository
Modelling of Daily PM2.5 in Thailand using Machine Learning on Remote Sensing Datasets
Limitations of using the model

name: Cross Country Relative Wealth Model for Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam
description: This is a cross-country sklearn Random Forest regressor model for predicting relative wealth for Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam. Through a post-training binning process, the model also predicts a quintile-grouped relative wealth category ('A' to 'E')  It is a cross-country model trained on open datasets from Earth Observation Group (EOG) nightlights data, Open Streetmap (OSM) Points of Interest (POI) data, Ookla internet speed data as well as Domestic and Health Survey (DHS) data from USAID.  Since DHS data is not available for Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam, DHS data from the Philippines, Cambodia, Myanmar and Timor Leste were combined  to train the model to be rolled out across these countries. It was built as part of the UNICEF AI4D Relative Wealth Project which aims to develop open datasets and machine learning (ML) models for relative wealth estimation across nine countries  in Southeast Asia (SEA).

link.description: Cross Country Model evaluation using Leave One Out Cross Country Country Validation (LOOC)
